abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. Lessons regarding design specify, and/or
            reinforce that when school communities manage resources,
            these are likely to be used more efficiently, being
            conducive to greater long term participation in school
            development. Within the framework of decentralization, the
            Central Government, through the Ministry of National
            Education (MONE) has a role in targeting strategies, to
            address the education needs of the poorest communities, if
            national goals for basic education are to be achieved.
            Lessons concerning management report that the matching grant
            mechanism for school quality improvement based on school
            plans, became problematic when the Government's
            development budgets were not released on time. Also, schools
            often found that the price of goods and services had changed
            between the time of preparing a proposal, and eventually
            receiving the goods. It took time for schools to learn how
            to match the books and equipment they ordered, with actual
            student needs and the teachers' ability to make
            effective use of them. Lessons regarding the project mapping
            suggest that expanded access, and other poverty-alleviation
            programs, and geographic targeting of services, should be
            done on the basis of poverty. Estimates should be made down
            to the village level, to benefit from mapping, an excellent
            technique to support this process, but there should be a
            pre-commitment to update the "map" each year -
            thereby overcoming the static nature of most poverty map schemes.
